description:
"A Bible-centered word building game for ages 9 and up."

A Scrabble-like board and letter tiles is used by a "Leader" to form five to eleven words related to the Bible, face-down except for the first letter.  Each square on the board has one, two, or three dots.  Players have tokens that move around the letters of the alphabet that encircle the board.  These letters have a numerical value associated with each, with (like Scrabble) the less often used letters having a higher value.

On their turn, players guess a letter in a single word, but are restricted to guessing the letter their token is on or one of the next seven letters.  The Leader moderates.  Players get points based on the value of the letter correctly guessed times the number of dots in the square it rests on.  Players may move their token ahead seven letters around the board instead of guessing, to get within range of a letter they want to guess.

The Leader keeps score, and the leading scorer when all the words are guessed wins.

D! Bone is a card game that combines the 5 point scoring system of Dominoes with the Spreads, Hits, and Wild Cards of Rummy. D! Bone uses special 2" x 3" cards designed exclusively for this game.

It takes a couple of hands to learn the rules,after that it's all about winning! If you're looking for a challenge, if you like creating strategy, and if you like winning, you will have hours of fun playing D! Bone!

2 to 4 players, ages 10 to adult

Island Hopping is how you get around in The Bahamas!  And it's also a lively game of strategy and chance.  As you play, you'll explore the country's beautiful islands and discover places you'd like to go.

You win the game by stacking four similar coins on one island.  But as you develop your winning strategy, remember that your best-laid plans can be sidetracked as the game takes you to unexpected destinations!

Opération Pedestal, published in Vae Victis issue #69 as a bonus solitaire-only mini-wargame, simulates the attack on Operation Pedestal in August 1942, of a convoy bound for Malta.  The player takes on the role of the Axis and must sink as many ships as possible, primarily  tankers.

Played on a polar grid with variable numbers of positions on each circumference. One piece-type only (stones), each player starts with 27 stones, 8 placed at specific starting positions, 19 off board. Two game phases : placement and then movement. Play usually alternates between players. Custodian capture applies during each phase, successful capture allows a second move. The two players have asymmetric goals, however: white must build a continuous line of pieces from center to circumference, black must prevent this from happening.

This is a simple but addictive 2 to 4 players race game (no dice are used) where the players ’fly’ their men across the board, racing to be the first to bear off all his men from the board.

In this game the players men are called Merels.

If you jump your opponent’s Merels, you go again; If you jump your own Merels, then you go again! So fly across the board in a single strike, or block & wait for a better opportunity in this multi-color, multi-level, multi-player race game! Recommended Ages 7+

Bunker Hill. Battle of the American Revolution. Card Game for 2 players. Separate Decks for the Americans & British. Cards represent Leaders, Troops, Fortifications, Shooting, Strategies, and Blunders. Unique Turn Sequencing results in Multiple possible Victory Conditions and Outcomes.

A SIMPLE CIVIL WAR GAME DELUXE © 2004
Simple wargame rules for re-fighting the Battle of Gettysburg
Game includes:

16-page rule book
32-page Armies of Gettysburg (Ratings for all regiments and leaders)
50 card movement and firing deck of cards (using Avery Business Card Template 5377)
Full Color cover sheet with “Grand Battery” errata on reverse side 
Players Aid sheet, 1- unit record sheet, and 1-sheet of game tables.

This simple tabletop game can be played with any Civil War miniatures you may have, or with something as simple as a set of wooden blocks painted blue and gray.

Combat is based on the “stand” (each stand representing 100 men, or 2 guns and crew)

Movement, combat, and morale are based (and modified) for the levels of command.
In these rules, leaders can make a real difference when units of equal capability and morale meet on the table-top. Card draw effects movement, combat, and time.

The 16-page rule book is easy to learn as the rule is on the left side of the page, and a photo, illustration, or highlight is on the right side of the page to clarify that rule or statement.

The 32-page “armies” booklet that rates each regiment, battery, and officer in the Army of the Potomac and Army of Northern Virginia for their performance during the Battle of Gettysburg and is organized by the UNION Corp or CONFEDERATE Division

1-set of 50 cards that control time, firing, movement, and “special situations” that might occur during a table-top battle. Each cycle of the deck is “1-hour” of game time.

These rules can use any of your existing miniatures, stand size makes no difference as long as both sides are mounted the same. If you do not have miniatures, or do not want to paint miniatures, a product called “ACW Paper Armies” is available for both sides. Individual “stands” show infantry, cavalry, artillery, commanders, wagons, and limbers in full color overhead photos.

Southern Front is the second supplement for Iron Stars, the game of space combat in an age of steam and steel. In this book players will find additional game mechanics and background material that extends our semi historical timeline through the pivotal year of 1912:


     An overview of world history from the close of the Merchant War through the Antarctic crisis;
     Nearly four dozen new ether ship designs, covering the space forces of South America, Italy, Turkey, and Spain, along with additional ships from Britain and Japan, and the introduction of the Soviet space forces;
     Coverage of the Falklands War between the British Empire and the A.B.C. Powers (Argentina, Brazil, and Chile), including nine new scenarios;
     "The Red One”, a short story by Jack London;
     A new space station, HMSS Diamond Rock;
     Rules for boarding parties and shipboard combat;
     New special equipment, such as star shells and heat rays; and
     Rules for orbital bombardment of surface targets.


This should be more than enough to keep your ether navies occupied as the world marches inexorably towards the Great War.

Southern Front includes nine (9) sheets of counters and templates for use with star shells and orbital bombardment.

Decode the ancient secrets of R'lyeh by forming words with the letters you find in this sanity-sapping letter game. The more angles that appear in the words, the greater their mystical value, but beware! For each word that is created, you must roll a sanity check against its value to see if the word's power drives you mad!

Cthulhu Mythos themed.

Awards:

     Games Magazine's 2007 Word Game of the Year.

The game of second chances

Do Over!™ is the fast paced game where everything can change at a moment’s notice. Just when you think you have your opponent right where you want them, it’s a “Do Over!” Look out for the “bomb” card, as it will level the payload you were about to unleash on your foe! Be the first to get rid of your cards to claim victory.

Try playing Do Over!™ just once - it’s a game you’ll want to “Do Over” again and again!

Combat Dominoes is a battle against the enemy's dominating dominoes in order to build a base and gain intelligence.  Infantry and special-ops dominoes are used in the fight to defeat the enemy in the domino warfare action.

Game play is similar to traditional domino games like All-Fives. The player with the highest double places it on the table facing horizontally. This becomes a separator that divides each player's base. On their turn, each player can place a domino only on their side of the divider, unless the other player runs out of viable plays, in which case their base becomes open to invasion by the opposing player.

Dominoes with blank ends have unique special-ops graphics printed on them. When special-ops dominoes are played, one of several events can occur, such as swapping domino tiles with the opposing player, or engaging in domino "combat."

The first player to shed all their dominoes wins the round. Points are tallied by adding up the number of pips from the dominoes still remaining in the loser's hand. The first player to accumulate 100 points wins the game.

In Red Dragon Inn, you and your friends are a party of heroic, fantasy adventurers. You've raided the dungeon, killed the monsters, and taken their treasure. Now you're back, and what better way to celebrate your most recent victory than to spend an evening at the Red Dragon Inn. You and your adventuring companions will spend the night drinking, gambling, and roughhousing. The last person who is both sober enough to remain conscious and shrewd enough to hold onto his Gold Coins wins the game.

The four characters are Deirdre the Priestess, Fiona the Volatile, Gerki the Sneak, and Zot the Wizard.

Master of Venice. Game of Renaissance Intrigue. You are a Merchant Family of Great Wealth & Prestige. Amass your Fortune by sending out your Cogs & Caravans along well Established Trade Routes. Buy Cardinals and Senators. Bid carefully in the Elections to gain control of the Doge and Pope. Beware Pirates, Plagues, Crusades, and Excommunications. All resources have a cost, and all have vulnerabilities. Game rules and card set available at: 
http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/MOV.html

Babylon's Burning is a near-future, post-apocalyptic skirmish game combining a gritty, atmospheric setting with rules that are both easy to learn and highly realistic.

The year is 2025 - 10 years after the Hit, the catastrophic meteor impact that tore society apart and set in motion a chain of events that left cities in ruins and 95% of the world's population dead and buried under a blanket of dust and ash. The survivors have banded together for mutual protection, resources are scarce and every other group is either a threat or an obstacle.
The background of the Babylon's Burning game is it's core - not a few paragraphs tagged on to the rules as an afterthought. You're introduced into the game with an extensive history of the Hit and an overview of the world of 2025 and drawn in further with the extensive fiction and the beautifully rendered and atmospheric original artwork that appears throughout.

The game mechanics are detailed but intuitive. This is a skirmish level game suitable for anything from a handful of troops to forty or so miniatures per side. Squads, solo elements (officers, snipers, medics and runners) and support weapons move according to a variable initiative system - there is no waiting around twiddling your thumbs while your opponent moves their entire force and the system is perfect for games with more than 2 players.

While it uses a fictional setting, Babylon's Burning recognizes the realities of modern combat. In order to come out on top, players need to keep moving, pick their targets well, take advantage of suppression and, most of all, utilize the terrain of tomorrow's shattered cities. This is a game that rewards players who ask themselves "what would I do?" - pushing blindly forward in tight formations is a good way to get very dead, very quickly.
Another advantage of the realistic setting is that there are no "super units" - in the confines of a dark alley, a nail-studded baseball bat is as deadly a weapon as any other...

The game accommodates a wide selection of faction types - Enclaves, Street Gangs, Mercs, Scavs, Ghouls, Culties, Mobs and Syndicates - all of them complete with their own restrictions and advantages. These factions don't just look different; they play differently too. From well armed Enclave militia built around a crack corps of pre-Hit professionals to street kid gangs moving about the table with dizzying speed on skateboards and roller blades, Babylon's Burning allows the player to choose the faction that best reflects their style of play.

FEATURES -

100 pages - looks great in color or black and white
Full-color counters and burst templates
Quick reference sheet and record sheets
Extensive scene-setting fiction by Jay Forster
Beautiful artwork by Elena Vanin, Jim Campbell and Craig Humpston

REVIEWS -

"The first thing to strike me was the very well produced and laid out format…the rules themselves are well thought out [with] plenty of examples interspersed in the text [and] are framed by an engrossing piece of fiction.

The best point of the rules is simply the fact that they are generic in their outlook - they are intended for use with any figures on the market, so they are not bound to a specific company's miniatures. This is a bonus, because you can use any figures you want, unlike some systems that insist on the sole use of 'official' figures."
(From the WARGAMES DIRECTORY review)

"The background material is very plausible and I think well researched as to the possibilities of this occurrence actually happening. I’ll not go into details about the background but lets just say it is indeed refreshing from the old nuclear exchange routine and I do think quite believable.

Gives a multitude of campaign and scenario options…the gaming possibilities are endless and I have admiration for these guys for the concept being a quite in depth look at what could happen in the near future, and I surmise a lot of thought and research must have gone into the whole planning of the background."
(From the WARGAMES FORUM review)

"We've been playing it, and loving it. The game is complex, detailed and easy to learn."
(From the APOCALYPSE FICTION review)

"Well produced and nicely laid out...the rules are supplied with a hefty set of appendices detailing the various forces that battle within the futuristic world of Babylon's Burning. There is no need to go out and buy an army book. There is plenty of choice here to keep you interested."
(From the MINIATURE REVIEW review)

From the publisher:
Kids will love the challenges of the Ice Age 2 Mammal Crossing Board Game. They'll embark on adventures with their favorite characters - trying to dodge rocks, serpents and geysers to get to safety! Be the first to reach the other side of the valley to win. Comes with four sculpted and painted character movers.

Seemingly another game similar to Perquackey or Scrabble Crossword Cubes Game.  May predate both of them.

Tumble Words  is a word dice game.

Sea Hunt Underwater Adventure Game is based on an old TV show from the late 1950's and early 1960's called "Sea Hunt" that starred Lloyd Bridges as Mike Nelson a skin diver. This game was made by Lowell Toy MFG. Corp., New York 56, N.Y. The copyright is listed as 1961 Ziv-United Artists, Inc. This is a spin and move game. The object of the game is to search areas of the sea for gold treasure.

Electronic talking Pop-o-Matic Trouble bubble "tells" you whether to discard or add cards to your hand with colorful lights and fun sound effects. Be the first player to discard your hand of cards and win the game! Includes Trouble bubble and deck of cards.

This game simulates the clash between Takeda Shingen and Uesugi Kenshin that took place near the Kawanakajima plains on September 10th, 1561 (1561 being Eiroku 4 in the calendar system of the time). This was the 4th, and greatest (yet still inconclusive) of the battles of Kawanakajima.

Many previous wargames use luck of the dice to determine the results of combat, but this game instead has players choose one of their combat cards, numbered 1-6, to resolve battles. Because of this, victory is determined not by the 'random factor' of one's luck with dice, but with 'reading and bluffing'.

In Die Nasionale Kruger-Wildtuin (aka The Kruger National Park) players take a tour of the Kruger National Park in South Africa, where the object is take photographs of as many animals as possible before visiting your three campsites and exiting the park.

Word in Progress is a sort of word game which turns the methodology of building complete words, as is found in word games such as Scrabble or Boggle, on its head.  In Word in Progress, players must work together to build partial words without being the player to complete an actual word, all the while attempting to discard as many of their respective points (letters) as possible before being eliminated from the round of play.

A sort of a proto-RPG using miniatures, set in the world of "Le Morte d'Arthur," which can be used to fight stand-alone melees, or to play extended campaigns.

Included are:
-rules for 1 on 1 melees and jousts that involves choosing cards representing various attacks or defenses.  Percentage dice are used to determine combat results, your chance to hit being determined by your and your opponent's choice of card.  The severity of the result is determined by the amount which your roll exceeds the base chance to hit

-simplified rules for combats involving multiple combatants

-rules for limited campaigns(lasting a few hours) and for longer campaigns of perhaps indefinite length.  The extended ("full") campaign includes rules for warfare and conquest and enable players to play enchanters as well as knights.  There are encounter tables and many rules designed to capture the flavor of the Arthurian mythos.

Goola is a advanced adaptation of "Connect Four" with some twists.  Players alternately drop one of their twenty "Goola" beads into one of the five slots in the Goola Tower trying to form a line of 4 or 5 beads of their color in order to accumulate points (1 point for a line of 4 and 2 points for a line of 5).  The twist here is that scoring only happens after all the beads are placed.  After the initial placement, each player then alternately operate one of the five mechanic valves at the bottom of the tower under each slot to make the beads drop one by one out the bottom of the tower.  After each bead drops out, each player count all the points they get for forming lines of 4 or 5 beads of the same color. The player with the higher points scores the difference in points on the scoreboard.  The first player to reach 8 points on the scoreboard wins.  A further twist can be found in the blind-play option built in the Goola Tower.  This advance play is similar to the basic game except that the bead placement is shielded from the players' sight, and the players must reply on memory to calculate where to place their beads.  After all the beads are played, the lock mechanism is released allowing the beads to drop into sight and the game continues as normal.

Game components:
40 Goola beads in two colors
1 Goola tower
1 Tower base with scoreboard
2 Goola stickers
1 Rulebook

Reach the top of the rock wall to complete this solitaire game, which uses a standard piecepack. In the game, you control the climber's hands and feet and also the position of the body in relation to the extremities. Find a way to move upwards choosing spots that are strong enough to support your weight.

The tiles make up the wall and the coins (suit up) the spots you can hold on to. 4 dice represent your 4 extremities and a pawn your "center of gravity". When you place an extremity in a spot you can hold on to, you flip the coin and it shows the maximum weight it can support. In addition, the farther an extremity is from the "center of gravity" the less weight it can support too. After moving the die to the new spot, you place it showing the weight it supports. The trick is to support your whole weight between the 4 extremities. Then, move your center of gravity to a new position where you can reach newer spots, finding your way through the wall.

A really quirky Red, White & Blue capture & replacement game (no points are scored) where the winner is the first player to have all his men in play on the board, however this is achieved.

In this game the player’s men are called Purim.

Once laid the Purim are neither ‘jumped’ or moved - but may be ‘returned to that player’s pot’. The key to this game is ‘Red, White, Blue. Red, White, Blue,,,etc’. Remember that & you cant go wrong. Recommended Ages 7+

The Cornish word for 'square', for 2 to many more players where the winner is the first player to complete a circuit of their score card, called their ‘Table card’.

In this game the players men are called Dan.

The sets themselves are made up of either:

a (A) set; Red, Yellow, Blue & Purple cards; Or

a (B) set; Black, White, Green & Brown cards.

Therefore with the adding together of further sets, e.g. 2 (A) sets, this would be a 2 to 4 player game with up to twenty-four Dan per player; or with the adding together of an (A) & a (B) set this would give a game for 2 to 8 players, with up to 12 Dan per player: Etc. There is no limit to how many sets can be added together to make a bigger and bigger game! Cracking. Recommended Ages 9+

The evil Piraka have invaded the island of Voya Nui and are now on the hunt for the powerful Mask of Life. Take up the Toa Inika mission to find the Mask before the Piraka. Traverse the island carefully, and be ready to do battle along the way.

Includes six exclusive collectible Toa Inika game pieces, a double-sided game board, a Protodermis ball launcher with Zamor sphere, a Piraka target, 50 Quest cards, and a die.

Players are parts of Reaver packs from Joss Whedon's "Firefly" universe. The goal is to raid planets and moons for victims. Winner is the first player to a 1000 body count. The board is a variable lay out of planets and moons with chits on them representing populations to ravage. Players move their ships from location to location and trying to over power what they find. Players use cards to increase their crew "packs" and give them bonuses as well as cards that effect the 'verse and other players. Players can upgrade ships to carry bigger crews.

A fan-made re-theme of BANG!, based on Joss Whedon's "Firefly" TV show. Instead of Sheriff, Deputy, Outlaw and Renegade, it's Captain, Crew, Local Color and The Merc. Characters are from the TV show, such as Wash, Mal, Book, Zoe, River, etc. Weapons and everything else is also based on the show; i.e. Vera (Weapon) and the Mule (Vehicle instead of Mount). And instead of Beer, you get Mudder's Milk.

Expanded by:


     BWAH!: Gorram Plans
     BWAH!: This Land 
     BWAH!: Local Color   
     BWAH! Can't Stop the Signal (Also plays as separate base game) 
     BWAH!: Those Left Behind  


Currently Active Download Links:


     http://www.fireflyfans.net/mthread.aspx?bid=13&tid=36208&mid=664346#664346
     http://jonathan.kc8onw.net/TCM%20Firefly%20Games/

From the Box:

"Take Two! is a fun-filled game for 2 or more that's a new game every time you play.  Arrange tiles randomly on the board, then start grabbing.  Everyone plays at once, grabbing matched pairs off the ends of the rows until the board is empty.  Whoever has the most matched pairs wins.  But choose carefully--and take a second look, because some pieces look almost alike.  If just one pair is mismatched, you lose."

This is best described as multi-player version of Mah Jong (solitaire version). It has a very frantic pace as everyone races to grab tiles.  Comes with a board with affixed plastic rows to keep the tiles in line, and 124 domino quality tiles.

One in a series of sixteen Flipsiders games designed to resemble pastel colored audio cassettes. The game contained a metal gameboard that would flip out with the snap of the wrist. A storage compartment at the top of the game would hold the magnetic pawns. A spring-loaded switch would spin the wheels of the cassette to generate random numbers and events during play. The game would hang from a blister pack on display at the store.

Players must advance toward and defeat in battle the boss alien on three levels to win. Defeat means starting a level all over again.

One in a series of sixteen Flipsiders games designed to resemble pastel colored audio cassettes. The game contained a metal gameboard that would flip out with the snap of the wrist. A storage compartment at the top of the game would hold the magnetic pawns. A spring-loaded switch would spin the wheels of the cassette to generate random numbers and events during play. The game would hang from a blister pack on display at the store.

The left spinner tells how far the players may advance during a turn. The right spinner tells the player whether or not one may advance when one reaches a barrier. The first to complete four trips through the mine is the winner.

One in a series of sixteen Flipsiders games designed to resemble pastel colored audio cassettes. The game contained a metal gameboard that would flip out with the snap of the wrist. A storage compartment at the top of the game would hold the magnetic pawns. A spring-loaded switch would spin the wheels of the cassette to generate random numbers and events during play. The game would hang from a blister pack on display at the store.

The left spinner is used to indicate upstream and downstream movement. The right spinner is used to indicate distance moved. The first player to reach the finish line is the winner.

A stand alone BWAH!! game that can be combined with the original if desired. BWAH! Can't Stop the Signal is based on the game BANG!! but set in the "Firefly" universe created by Joss Whedon. This one is based on the movie "Serenity" and not directly the show. The game uses the same mechanics as BWAH! and BANG! except the characters and professions are from the movie. Some examples are Wash, Zoe, and Mal as characters and Psychic, Crew, Captain, Reavers, and Operative as professions. Health is recovered by eating Fruity Oaty Bars.

Bumper Car Arena is OGP's first full blown board game.  Earlier offerings were more along the Cheapass Game quality of components.  In this game, the components are quite good.  This is a race game with pre-programmed movement ala Roborally.  Players also score points for knocking into their opponents.  The last place player also controls the "rogue" bumper car, Jimmy Fudge -- who only wants to bump other players.

Each player controls one bumper car. Simultaneous movement card play determines the movement order. Players score points for moving around the track in the appropriate direction, and for bumping other bumper cars. Draws are done from a face up draft of n+1 cards where n is the number of players. The remaining card is used to control Jimmy Fudge's bumper car. Play continues until someone has scored 21 points, thereafter, there is an increasing chance of the game ending every turn.

From the Publisher:

It's a beautiful day at the amusement park. You and your friends have decided to take over the bumper car ride for your own purposes. Players score points for bumping other players cars and going around the track in the proper direction. (Going backwards makes the carnies angry.) And who is this Jimmy Fudge kid anyway?

From publisher Parker Brothers: Rewind the decade of yuppies, big hair and break dancing! This edition of the popular trivia game has cool retro packaging and 2400 trivia questions in six categories to take you back to the colorful 80s! Includes 4 collectible tokens based on 80s icons. For 2-4 players or teams.

Categories in this edition are headlines, television, movies, music, sports & leisure, and wild card.

Hunters in the Sky is a complete miniatures game of WWII air combat. The basic rules allow for relatively large battles with up to a dozen aircraft per side and minimal record keeping.

Optional rules are included which cover; air to ground combat, bombers (dive, level and torpedo), variable pilot quality and experience, and simple campaign system.

Advanced rules which add realism include; advanced maneuvering, deflection shooting, visual spotting, limited ammunition, critical damage, and more...

Also included is the Warbirds aircraft lists, with game stats for 118 different aircraft from 10 different nations.
28 pages.

"Hunters in the sky is by far the best WWII aircraft game I have ever played! If you do not have this in your collection then SHAME ON YOU! BUY IT NOW!"  -  R.A. June 2006

Download version can be purchased at www.wargamedownloads.com

From Dr. Toy:

"There are 1,200 questions included in this innovative game. It is available in French and English. This game is perfect for children 6 and over. There are three questions on each card: one is aimed at younger children (6-7 yrs.) the second aimed for older(8-9 yrs) and the third aimed for 10 to 12 years old children. Everyone at all ages can play the game together. The first player or team to complete the jigsaw puzzle wins. Most questions are based on actual school textbooks."

Expanded by:

    McWiz Junior Booster Bus: The Bus of Knowledge in Math

From Discovery Toys:

"In a fast-paced race against the clock, build as many words as you can and strengthen phonics and spelling skills. Players at different reading levels can play at the same time using specified combinations of colored rods. Or practice with basic word families, rhyming words and blended sounds at your own pace with the included activity book (used in schools to teach reading). Especially helpful for kinesthetic and visual learners."

From the Publisher's Website at http://www.hyperion-games.com/dil01.html **
    


"The Dilbert Principle:
The most ineffective workers are systematically moved to the place where they can do the least damage: management.

Welcome to the absurdities of the business world: a place of rightsizing, vision statements, bungee bosses, peer reviews, total quality management and team-building exercises; a place where millennia of evolution is put to use in the struggle for the best cubicle and competition over office furniture.

In Dilbert™ the Board Game you and up to five friends toil in an office of evil HR directors, accounting trolls, canine consultants, and a boss who bears a suspicious resemblance to the devil. Every project assigned to you is doomed from the start, so your best bet is to dump it on someone else or try to get it killed before it eats away any more of your life. In fact, the only thing that really matters in the end is your own happiness. So why bother with work?

Dilbert™ is a hilarious board game for 3-6 players ages 14 and up, and requires about 90 minutes to play. "

The first matching game using wildlife photos which were taken directly from DK's best selling children's books.

Classic bingo is only one of the variations which are described in the rules pamphlet, as young players are challenged to work on matching, sorting, and language skills

A perfect first game for the children...

From the Rules of Play:

STARGO is a fun and engaging way to introduce kids to the basic concepts of stars, galaxies and constellations. There are two ways to play, and both are based on Bingo. Version "A" uses basic number and color concepts as players search for stars on one constellation. Version "B" uses basic visual and memory skills as players enjoy traditional Bingo on a grid featuring 24 constellations.

				
				
					Version A:

There are 30 large glossy cards, each featuring a constellation with numbered, colored stars (that glow in the dark!). Each player selects one. Colored and numbered stars are selected from the bag and called -- first to complete his constellation wins.

Version B:

On the flip side of the constellation cards is a traditional Bingo grid of constellations. Constellations are selected from a deck (each has information about that constellation on the back). First to complete five in a row wins.

				
				
					The constellation cards feature glow in the dark stars and an orienting arrow. Combined with the included compass, they can be used to help find those constellations in the night sky. The smaller cards contain facts about the constellations and the stars within them. The rulebook also contains information about stargazing.

Die Angelschlacht (the pivotal battle) 1944 covers the 25th SS PG\12SS Panzer division's counterattack on June 7th against the strung out Canadian forces west of Caen. The 12thSS struck with 45 tanks and quickly advanced causing a panic to the allies. The Canadians had little armor and were out of artillery range. The battle lasted 6 hours and the SS advanced only a few miles but this attack delayed the allied advance for another 30 days! The game has over 280 counters and one 11x17" map, rulebook. Include in the game are unique random events that makes game play never the same. For those interested in historical or what games, player's may choose to do either. The game contains many scenarios.

Each hex is 200-250 yds, each turn is 30 min. Units are company level, each with a morale and movement rating. Actual fire strengths depend on the unit firing, type of attack, range to target, and weapon firing. New rules cover random events, anti-aircraft fire, air units, M10's, Panther tanks.

Rare German Space Battle System based on the famous German Sci-Fi Novels.

Ever wanted to take a seat behind the command panel of the battleship STARDUST and personally lead the pride of the Terran Navy into battle? Now it is possible.

The first in a series of games based on the world-renowned Perry Rhodan series - the space combat system! A new, easy-to-use control system enables a "realistic" and detailed simulation of events that are typical of a battle in the endless expanses of space. You can decide for yourself whether two individual ships should fight a duel or whether whole formations should collide, and otherwise you are the one who makes the decisions.

Tactical movement, deceleration or acceleration, short transition or emergency jump, volleys, point fire or full broadside, everything is in your hands. The game material you have at your disposal is a playing surface measuring 59 x 42 cm, a rule book, a scenario book, a set of data sheets, 56 pages of background material, 180 game pieces and two twenty-sided dice.


Wollten Sie schon immer einmal hinter dem Kommandopult des Schlachtschiffes STARDUST Platz nehmen und den Stolz der terranischen Raumflotte persönlich ins Gefecht führen? Jetzt ist es möglich.

Als erstes einer Reihe von Spielen mit dem Hintergrund der weltbekannten Perry Rhodan-Serie erhältlich - das Raumkampfsystem! Ein neuartiges, leicht zu handhabendes Regelsystem ermöglicht eine "realistische" und detailgetreue Simulation von Geschehnissen, wie sie für ein Gefecht in den endlosen Weiten des Weltraums typisch sind. Ob zwei einzelne Raumer ein Duell miteinander ausfechten oder ganze Verbände aufeinander prallen sollen, können Sie selbst entscheiden, und auch sonst sind Sie es, der die Entscheidungen trifft..

Taktische Bewegung, Abbremsen oder Beschleunigen, Kurztransition oder Notsprung, Salven, Punktfeuer oder volle Breitseite, alles lieggt in Ihrer Hand. Als Spielmaterial steht Ihnen dabei eine Spielfläche von 59 x 42 cm, ein Regelband, ein Szenarioband, ein Satz Datenblätter, 56 Seiten Hintergrundmaterial, 180 Spielsteine und zwei zwanzigseitige Würfel zur Verfügung."

Switch is the first of the small box games published by Pseudon and is noted with "#1" on the spine. The game includes 16 tiles which are first laid out for all to see. The tiles are then flipped, and in turn a player must flip two to find the scoring combinations on the score sheet. The winner of the game is the first to make all the combinations on their score sheet.

Captain Morgan's Wrath is the pirate drinking game by Party Hard Corps. Spinning a tee-totum (think a dreidel), the players are encouraged to be as loud with their yaaaaars as possible while the it spins, or even bang on the table to try to make a player "walk the plank!" First player with five doubloons and the captain's patch is the commodore, and the winner- unless the crew mutinies, and leaves that land lubber on an uncharted island!

Players begin with 4,000 dollars and have the chance to make a fortune or go broke by investing in farms and farm related businesses. A property can be purchased only by landing on it and each time a player must decide whether to invest his limited funds or to hope for something better among the 28 farms and 9 businesses available along the track. Cheaper properties are easier to develop but have a smaller payoff when landed on by an opponent. (just like Monopoly). Another decision must be made regarding the 3 different kinds of crops that may be planted on each farm. Again cheaper pays off sooner but in smaller amounts. Once the crop is in a player can add farm equipment in the form of plastic "silo sections" which are piled in strict color sequence. Limited quantities of the best crops and the highest silo section adds to the decision making process. A player may mortgage a property to pay debt or to make other investments and can still collect 10% of his normal fee from a visiting opponent. Other features include taxes, becoming incorporated, luck cards which can be disastrous, selling properties to an opponent or the treasury.

This game features 96 "domino" tiles, consisting of different pairings of the 12 zodiac symbols. Each symbol appears red and black. Twelve of the tiles have stars at one end and are "wild". 2 to 4 players play, each using a rack of 6 tiles. Tiles can be placed anywhere in the layout provided that they match the same symbol in opposite color of at least one face that has been previously played. Notches on the tiles help keep the layout securely in place. The score for a play depends on the number of matches which, in rare cases, can be as many as 6. If a player can make a match on at least one face of his tile he may play a second or third and so on up to all 6 tiles from his hand. Play ends when, after all the tiles have been drawn a player clears his rack, earning a bonus. High score wins

“Millennium – the millennium game” (as it would be literally - and rather silly - translated into English) is a memory game with a twist meets a historical trivia game. The game board shows an event, an important person or anything characteristic for each decade from 10 to 2000 (with the exception of 500, 1000 and 1500) represented in nice comic art as well as text and arranged in a huge spiral covering almost the complete board.
At the beginning of the game, the players cover 10 of the decades one by one with cardboard disks numbered from 1 to 10, while reading out the year and the accompanying text. E.g. “10 Emperor Augustus”, “1060 William the Conqueror”, “1190 The third Crusade” or “1770 The USA”. 
Each player then gets ten transparent plastic chips. The goal of the game is to get rid of these chips by correctly remembering the events etc. under the numbered cardboard disks. In each turn, initially the player rolls a d12. Then he has to repeat the decade and the text under the corresponding disk. Only if he succeeds, he may return one chip to the box and replace the disk on a new decade; in any case, the next player gets to roll the die. The 11 and 12 on the die have special functions:
When rolling 11, the player may place one of his chips on a cardboard disk of his choice. The next player who rolls the corresponding number has to take this chip before trying to remember what is underneath.
When rolling 12, the player asks the player with the most chips left to remember what is under a disk of his choice. If the other player succeeds, he may place one of his chips on the disk and replace the disk, otherwise, the first player has to solve the task. If he does not succeed either, the player with the most chips may give him one of his chips.
Apart from the material described, Millennium contains a small almanac (30 pg.) with a short description of each decades event, person etc.
